questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with viral myositis. Viral myositis is an inflammation of the muscles caused by viral infection, often following an upper respiratory tract illness. The condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Recent viral illness: The history of fever and cough 3 days prior suggests a preceding viral infection, which is a common trigger for viral myositis.
  • Leg pain and muscle tenderness: Viral myositis often presents with significant muscle soreness, especially in the calf muscles, leading to pain on palpation.
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels: The CK level of 2000 IU indicates muscle injury or inflammation, which is consistent with viral myositis.
  • Normal reflexes and neurological examination: This helps differentiate viral myositis from other conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which would typically present with abnormal reflexes or progressive muscle weakness.

 

Influenza is a common viral cause of myositis, particularly in children. The muscle pain typically begins 1-7 days after the onset of the viral illness and may lead to difficulty walking, often with a characteristic toe-walking gait due to involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, typically presenting with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK levels. However, it does not present acutely following a viral illness and usually starts earlier in life.

 

Option C. GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome): GBS is an autoimmune condition that causes ascending paralysis, starting with weakness in the legs. Reflexes are usually diminished or absent in GBS, unlike the normal reflexes observed in this case.

 

Option D. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It usually presents with chronic, progressive weakness rather than acute pain following a viral illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

choices.text: Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year

 

Correct sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

 

Normal length of a newborn - 48-50cm (increase by 50% at 1st year = 75cm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year: An infant gain weight at a rate of approximately 20-40 g per day for the first 3 months of life. Thereafter, they gain about 400 g weight every month for the remaining part of the first year.

 

Option C. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age:

 

 

Option D. Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile: According to WHO growth charts, weight and height under 50th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in length by 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: partial deletion of short arm of Chr 5, leads to cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.
  • Bloom syndrome: rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer and genomic instability.
  • Angelman syndrome: caused by deletion in maternal chromosome 15 or paternal uniparental disomy, affects nervous system, delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.
  • Fragile X syndrome: genetic disorder, also known as Martin-Bell syndrome, most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: features are:

 

  • Short stature
  • Sun sensitive rash over the nose and nose and cheeks
  • Immune deficiency 
  • Insulin resistance that resembles Type 2 Diabetes

 

The question doesn’t mention such feature. Therefore, bloom syndrome is not the right answer

 

Option C. Angelman syndrome: remember “angel is the mother” therefore, in this syndrome maternal gene is deleted. It is one of the examples of uniparental disomy. The clinical features are:

 

 

  1. Maternal gene is deleted
  2. Paternal gene is doubled
  3. Dev delay
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Microcephaly
  6. Hyperactive
  7. Spontaneous laughter - Happy Puppets
  8. Hypertonia
  9. UBE3A GENE ON Chr 15 is defective/absent

 

Option D. fragile x syndrome: it is the second most common non preventable cause of mental retardation. The features are:

 

  1. Male patient
  2. Large ears
  3. Large testes
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Nose will NOT be large

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: The fetal adrenal gland production of which of the following is maximum? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DHEA

 

The fetal adrenal gland primarily produces Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and its sulfate form, DHEA-S, in significant quantities during pregnancy. DHEA and DHEA-S are essential precursors for the synthesis of estrogens. These precursors are crucial because the fetal adrenal gland produces much more DHEA-S than the maternal adrenal gland, making it the most important source of estrogen precursors for the placenta.

 

During pregnancy, these estrogens play a vital role in maintaining the pregnancy and supporting fetal development. The high production of DHEA by the fetal adrenal gland underlines its significant contribution to the endocrine environment during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: While cortisol is produced by the fetal adrenal gland, its production is not as high as DHEA. Cortisol plays a role in fetal lung maturation, but it is not produced in maximum amounts compared to DHEA.

 

Option C. Corticosterone: Corticosterone is another steroid hormone produced by the adrenal gland but in much smaller quantities than DHEA.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily produced by the placenta during pregnancy, and the adrenal gland's contribution to its levels is minimal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fetal adrenal gland produces the maximum amount of DHEA, which is a precursor for estrogen synthesis, critical for maintaining pregnancy and supporting fetal development.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
  2. PT and APTT
  3. Bone marrow
  4. Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

The clinical presentation, along with the findings of the peripheral blood smear and a Mentzer index of less than 13, suggests a diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A hemoglobinopathy characterized by a deficiency in the synthesis of one of the globin chains, either alpha or beta. In beta-thalassemia, there is reduced synthesis of beta chains, leading to decreased levels of hemoglobin A (HbA) and increased levels of HbA2 and HbF.
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): This test is crucial for diagnosing thalassemia as it can detect changes in hemoglobin levels, specifically the increased levels of HbA2 and HbF that are characteristic of beta-thalassemia. HPLC is sufficient for diagnosis without the need for bone marrow investigations.
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: The smear may reveal aniso-poikilocytosis, target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells, which are indicative of thalassemia.
  • Mentzer Index: The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV/RBC count, helps differentiate thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia. A value of less than 13 suggests thalassemia, while a value greater than 13 suggests iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

2 (PT and APTT): These tests are not directly relevant for the diagnosis of thalassemia. PT (Prothrombin Time) is used to assess the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) assesses the intrinsic pathway, typically done when bleeding disorders are suspected.

 

3 (Bone Marrow): Bone marrow examination is not necessary in this case as the diagnosis of thalassemia can be made based on HPLC and peripheral smear findings. Bone marrow investigations are more appropriate for cases of pancytopenia or unexplained anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva of the eye and are caused by the keratinization of the epithelial cells. These spots are a specific sign of vitamin A deficiency, which is crucial for maintaining healthy epithelial tissues and normal vision. The deficiency leads to dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, ultimately causing these characteristic spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vogts stria: Vogts stria is associated with keratoconus, a condition where the cornea thins and gradually bulges outward into a cone shape, leading to vision problems.

 

Option B. Arlts line: Arlts line is related to trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, leading to roughening of the inner surface of the eyelids.

 

Option D. Harnor tantra dots: Harnor tantra dots are focal white limbal dots consisting of degenerated epithelial cells and eosinophils, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is specifically associated with Bitot spots, characterized by keratin deposits on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

 

 

 

A, Alport syndrome (EM), Note the presence of both the characteristic “basket- weave” change (asterisks) and thinning of the GBM (arrows).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is an immune-mediated disease characterised by antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary, and light microscopy reveals extracapillary growth with crescents and necrosis.

 

Option C. IgA nephropathy: In IgA nephropathy, light microscopy would demonstrate focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis and mesangial widening.

 

Option D. PSGN:  In PSGN, light microscopy would reveal diffuse endocapillary proliferation with concomitant leukocytic infiltration in LM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the case presented is atopic dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition often associated with the atopic state, which includes eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. This condition is characterized by impaired epidermal barrier function, often due to a genetic predisposition. In many patients, a mutation in the filaggrin gene is responsible for this barrier defect.

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with:

 

  • Eczematous lesions: These lesions are often red, inflamed, and may ooze or become crusted. They frequently occur in flexural areas such as the elbows, knees, and neck.
  • Pruritus (itching): Intense itching is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, often leading to scratching that can exacerbate the lesions.
  • Chronic course: The condition usually has a chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission. Lesions often persist for more than 6 weeks.
  • Family history: There is often a personal or family history of atopic conditions, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, or food allergies.
  • Lichenification: Chronic scratching may lead to thickened, leathery skin, known as lichenification.

 

The clinical image provided shows red, excoriated lesions in the flexure aspect of the elbow, which is highly characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, not with the eczematous lesions seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. It is not associated with the flexural distribution or the intense pruritus seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Post-traumatic pigmentation: This refers to skin discoloration following an injury. It does not present with eczematous lesions or intense itching, and it is not limited to flexural areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ataxia Telangiectasia is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selective absence of IgM

 

Explanation:

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT) is a complex genetic disorder characterized by progressive neurological decline, immunodeficiency, and increased cancer risk. The incorrect statement among the options is the selective absence of IgM. In reality, the most common immunodeficiency in AT involves a reduction or absence of IgA, not IgM. Patients with AT typically exhibit normal IgM levels, but often have reduced levels of IgA, which is crucial in mucosal immunity, leading to their increased susceptibility to respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Premature ageing: Correct, AT is associated with premature ageing, which is part of the broader spectrum of symptoms due to its impact on cellular repair and increased oxidative stress.

 

Option C. Insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus: Correct, although less common than other features, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus can occur in AT due to pancreatic involvement.

 

Option D. Progressive Cerebellar Ataxia: Correct, this is one of the hallmark symptoms of AT, typically manifesting early in childhood and progressively worsening, often confining individuals to a wheelchair by adolescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia is associated with a selective absence of IgA, not IgM, which contributes to the immunodeficiency seen in these patients, leading to recurrent respiratory infections.

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.2 kg develops feeding intolerance and abdominal distension on the second day. Physical examination is unremarkable, and the sepsis screen is negative. PCV is observed to be 72%. Which of the following represents the best management option? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Partial exchange transfusion

 

Explanation:

 

A hematocrit of 72% in a 2-day-old neonate indicates neonatal polycythemia. Symptoms such as feeding intolerance and abdominal distension are common gastrointestinal manifestations of this condition. The appropriate management for symptomatic polycythemia with a hematocrit of 72% is partial exchange transfusion (PET). This procedure reduces the hematocrit to a safer level, decreasing blood viscosity and improving tissue perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydration with IV fluids: While hydration can be useful for mild cases, it is insufficient for a neonate with symptomatic polycythemia and a high hematocrit.

 

Option C. Presumptive treatment for sepsis: This is not indicated as the sepsis screen is negative.

 

Option D. Medical management for intestinal obstruction: This is not appropriate as the symptoms are due to polycythemia, not intestinal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for symptomatic neonatal polycythemia with a hematocrit of 72% is partial exchange transfusion.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVIG

 

The clinical presentation of fever, congested conjunctiva, strawberry tongue, and red skin peeling, along with the echocardiogram finding of a coronary aneurysm, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms if not treated promptly.

 

Initial Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for Kawasaki disease is the administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG is given to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms, which is the most serious complication of Kawasaki disease. The standard dose is 2 g/kg administered as a single infusion, usually within the first 10 days of illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is also used in the management of Kawasaki disease, typically in conjunction with IVIG. However, IVIG is the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent coronary complications.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent, but it is not part of the initial treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option D. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is an anticoagulant, but it is not used as the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy


The clinical presentation described is consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions typically involving both arms. These jerks are most frequent in the morning, often leading to the dropping of objects, as described in this case. The patient maintains consciousness during these episodes, which is typical for JME.

 

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

 

  • Myoclonic jerks: The hallmark seizure type in JME, often occurring shortly after waking up in the morning.
  • Maintained consciousness: The patient remains aware during the myoclonic jerks.
  • Triggers: Seizures can be triggered by stimuli such as sleep deprivation, stress, and photic stimulation (e.g., flashing lights).
  • Genetics: A mutation in the GABRA1 gene is associated with JME.
  • Treatment: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
  • Prognosis: Generally good with appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical absence: Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness without motor symptoms like dropping objects. Atypical absences last longer than typical ones and have slower onset and resolution.

 

Option C. Choreo-athetoid epilepsy: This condition involves involuntary irregular movements of the face, head, trunk, and extremities, which does not align with the symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Centrotemporal spikes: Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), also known as Rolandic epilepsy, involves brief stereotypical partial seizures, typically with facial and oropharyngeal involvement, not consistent with the symptomatology in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

 

In the management of severe COVID-19 in children, corticosteroids are the primary treatment among the given options. Corticosteroids are recommended for children with severe cases, which include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as SpO2 less than 90% on room air, severe chest retractions, grunting, lethargy, and signs of pneumonia with cyanosis. In these cases, corticosteroids like Dexamethasone or Methylprednisolone are used to reduce inflammation and manage the severe immune response associated with the virus.

 

Guidelines for Steroid Use in Severe COVID-19:

 

  • Indications: Corticosteroids are indicated in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases. They are generally avoided in the first 3-5 days of illness due to the risk of increased viral shedding during this period.
  • Dosage: Dexamethasone is given at a dose of 0.15 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 6 mg once a day, or Methylprednisolone at 0.75 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 30 mg once a day.
  • Duration: The treatment typically continues for 5-6 days and then is tapered off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is not recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children. Ivermectin has been used for deworming, not for treating COVID-19.

 

Option C. Remdesivir: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication used in some hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 but is not the primary treatment for severe cases in children. It inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate. Based on heart rate, the response to newborn resuscitation is evaluated at different stages.

 

  • If the heart rate is under 100, PPV is given, SPO2 is monitored, and sufficient breathing is guaranteed.
  • Chest compressions are started over the lower portion of the sternum at a pace of 90 compressions per minute if the heart rate is below 60. The ventilation to compression ratio is 3 to 1.
  • IV epinephrine is administered if the heart rate is still below 60 despite effective compressions and breathing.


 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is not a sign of effective resuscitation.

 

Option B. Bilateral air entry: this feature is checked when we are thinking of pneumothorax or severe pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum and is typically limited by the edges of the skull bones. It does not cross suture lines because the bleeding is confined by the bone edges. This differentiates it from other types of scalp swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to diffuse swelling of the scalp that crosses the suture lines and extends beyond the presenting part of the baby's head. It is caused by pressure from the birth canal during delivery.

 

Option C. Subgaleal hematoma: A subgaleal hematoma is a collection of blood between the scalp galea aponeurosis and the periosteum of the skull. It typically presents as a diffuse, boggy swelling that can cross suture lines and extend over large areas of the scalp.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the image and description fit the characteristics of a cephal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Spinal dysraphism includes-

 

Open spinal dysraphism: Myelomeningocele, meningocele

Occult spinal dysraphism:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Spinal lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Tethered cord
  • Split cord malformation (diastematomyelia)
  • And others
     

 

 

 

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

 

By the age of 24 months (2 years), most children develop the ability to use a spoon and feed themselves, which is a key fine motor skill. By the age of 3 years, this skill is typically well established, allowing the child to handle a spoon with greater proficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one foot: Hopping on one foot is a motor milestone that typically develops around the age of 4 years. Skipping usually comes later, around 5 years.

 

Option C. Copying a triangle: The ability to copy shapes such as a triangle is generally seen around 5 years of age. More complex shapes like a diamond are usually copied around 7 years of age.

 

Option D. Repeats sentences of 10 syllables: A child's ability to repeat longer sentences, including those with 10 syllables, generally develops around 4 to 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:


By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PSGN

 

  • The clinical picture points to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. (PSGN).
  • PSGN is characterised by sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.
  • Most children recover entirely from hematuria and proteinuria within 3-6 weeks of the beginning of nephritis after a throat infection with nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci. However, between 3 and 10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

 

Light microscopy reveals larger, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix in PSGN. In the early stages, polymorph neutrophils (PMN) infiltrate.

 

Immunofluorescence: "Lumpy-bumpy" IgG and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and

 

Electron microscopy- humps are seen on epithelial side of glomerular basement membrane

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrolithiasis: Nephrolithiasis will have features of kidney stones in ultrasound. Symptoms: dysuria, hypogastric pain, hematuria & repeated urinary infections.

 

Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve: this is one of the cause of distal urinary tract obstruction in boys. Clinical features, abnormal urinary stream, dribbling, palpable bladder & recurrent UTI.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Blood pressure of the patient will be normal. Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 Weeks

 

Congenital biliary atresia is a condition where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to bile accumulation in the liver. This condition often presents with jaundice that persists beyond the normal neonatal period.

 

This option is correct. If jaundice is present beyond the first 2 weeks of an infant's life, it is a significant indicator to suspect congenital biliary atresia. Early diagnosis is crucial for better outcomes, and any persistent jaundice beyond this period warrants further investigation for possible biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond 2 weeks.

questions.text: A child with Celiac disease can be given: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rice


Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats (referred to by the mnemonic "BROW"). Individuals with celiac disease must strictly avoid these grains and any foods containing gluten.

 

Rice is naturally gluten-free and is safe for individuals with celiac disease. It is a staple food that can be consumed without concern for gluten contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sooji: Sooji, also known as semolina, is made from wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for someone with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Oat: Oats can be contaminated with gluten during processing, and even gluten-free oats might not be well tolerated by all individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, oats are generally avoided unless they are certified gluten-free and tolerated by the patient.

 

Option D. Broken wheat/daliya: Broken wheat, also known as daliya, is another form of wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for individuals with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Celiac patients must avoid gluten-containing grains like barley, rye, oats, and wheat (BROW). Rice is a safe and gluten-free option for these patients.

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

 

The 5th disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It is a common childhood viral infection characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: This is not correct. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option C. HFMD (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease): HFMD is caused by enteroviruses, primarily Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is not caused by Parvovirus B19. It is an inflammatory condition of blood vessels, and its etiology is not related to the virus responsible for the 5th disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

     

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation is a safety feature designed to release pressure when it exceeds a certain limit to prevent barotrauma to the patient. This valve typically releases at a pressure range of 30-40 cm of water (H2O). This pressure setting helps ensure that the air is delivered to the patient safely without causing excessive force that could damage the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is a condition that arises from excessive alcohol exposure during pregnancy, which leads to a range of developmental abnormalities. FAS is characterized by several key features, including facial anomalies, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and growth deficiencies.

 

  • Facial Anomalies: The classic facial features of FAS include small eye openings (narrow palpebral fissures), a smooth philtrum (the area between the nose and upper lip), and a thin upper lip. Other features may include epicanthic folds, a flattened nasal bridge, a short nose, low-set and unparallel ears, and midfacial hypoplasia.
  • CNS Dysfunction: This includes microcephaly (small head size), mental retardation, and neurobehavioral abnormalities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The presence of microcephaly is a common finding in FAS, reflecting the overall poor brain growth and development.
  • Thinning of Corpus Callosum: FAS can lead to structural brain abnormalities such as thinning or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum, which is the band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Holoprosencephaly: This is a severe brain malformation where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres, which can be seen in more severe cases of FAS.

 

Macrocephaly (enlarged head size) is not a feature of FAS. On the contrary, FAS is typically associated with microcephaly, reflecting the impaired brain growth caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a known CNS abnormality in FAS, reflecting the significant impact of alcohol on brain structure and development.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: One of the hallmark features of FAS, microcephaly indicates reduced brain size and development, commonly seen in affected infants.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: This severe brain malformation can occur in the context of FAS, particularly in cases where the alcohol exposure has profoundly disrupted early brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: A child presented in the pediatric OPD with fever for past 5 days along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis. The mother also complained of a non itchy rash that appeared just a day back starting from behind the ears involving the face and spreading to the trunk also involving palms and soles. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles


The clinical presentation described is characteristic of measles, a viral infection caused by the measles virus. Measles typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis, often referred to as the "3 C's" of measles. These symptoms are followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash that typically starts behind the ears, spreads to the face, and then to the rest of the body, including the trunk, palms, and soles.

 

The hallmark features of measles include the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a characteristic rash that spreads from the head downward to the rest of the body. This description fits the scenario provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, presents with a milder illness compared to measles. The rash in rubella usually starts on the face and spreads to the body but is typically accompanied by mild fever and swollen lymph nodes, especially behind the ears. The rash in rubella is often itchy, which contrasts with the non-itchy rash described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Dengue: Dengue fever presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, rash, and bleeding tendencies. Thrombocytopenia and other signs of bleeding are common in dengue, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is not applicable as the clinical features align with a diagnosis of measles.

 

Educational Objective:


Measles is characterized by the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a non-itchy rash that spreads from behind the ears to the rest of the body, including the palms and soles.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. In the proximal calf

 

Explanation:

 

Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located in the proximal calf region. It is one of the important named perforator veins that forms a direct communication between the superficial and deep venous systems. Specifically, Boyd's perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the deep veins (posterior tibial vein) at the level of the proximal calf. This perforator is clinically significant in patients with chronic venous insufficiency as incompetence in this perforator can contribute to varicose veins and venous hypertension.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. In the proximal thigh: This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's.
  • Option B. In the distal thigh: Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location.
  • Option D. In the distal calf: This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Boyd's perforator is located in the proximal calf, serving as an important communication between the great saphenous vein and deep posterior tibial vein. Its incompetence plays a significant role in the development of venous hypertension and varicose veins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF to improve child health in developing countries. The child's symptoms of eagerly drinking water and a slow skin pinch return are indicative of some dehydration, which falls under the yellow category in the IMNCI guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green: The green category denotes "no dehydration." This would be for a child who shows no signs of dehydration and is otherwise healthy.

 

Option C. Pink: The pink category denotes "severe dehydration." Signs of severe dehydration include lethargy, unconsciousness, very dry mouth, and a skin pinch that goes back very slowly.

 

Option D. Black: This is an incorrect option as the IMNCI color coding does not include black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI color coding system:

 

  • Green indicates no dehydration.
  • Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder Exstrophy  


The correct diagnosis is Bladder Exstrophy, a congenital condition where the bladder is turned inside out and exposed outside the body. It typically presents with an open, red mass in the lower abdominal area, often just below the umbilical cord, which is consistent with the image provided. This condition occurs due to a failure in the development of the abdominal wall and urogenital structures, leading to the bladder being exposed outside the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines, liver, and other organs protrude outside of the abdomen through the umbilical ring but are covered by a thin membrane or sac. The characteristic feature is that the protruding organs are enclosed in a sac, unlike in bladder exstrophy, where no covering sac is present.

 

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is another abdominal wall defect where the intestines protrude outside of the body but without any covering membrane, typically located to the right of the umbilical cord. However, it does not involve the bladder and appears distinctly different as only intestines are seen without any protective sac.

 

 

Option D. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital condition resulting from an incomplete obliteration of the vitellointestinal duct. It is a small pouch on the wall of the lower part of the small intestine and does not involve external defects or protrusions visible on the abdominal surface. It usually presents with painless rectal bleeding or obstruction.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Bladder Exstrophy is characterized by the bladder being exposed outside the body, appearing as a red mass in the lower abdomen with no covering membrane. It differs from other abdominal wall defects like omphalocele and gastroschisis, which involve the protrusion of abdominal contents with or without a protective sac.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.
