Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood that has not been processed by the liver into its conjugated form. Gilbert syndrome is a common genetic disorder that causes mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition results from reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: (Mnemonic: DR BHATIA)

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the liver's ability to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts, leading to its buildup in the liver.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome also leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition that results from a defect in the hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This condition also results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a serious liver disease in infants where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, preventing bile from draining from the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the image. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focal clonic seizure.

 

The movements depicted in the clip are indicative of a focal clonic seizure. In neonates, focal clonic seizures are characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. These contractions can involve the limbs, face, or trunk. Key characteristics of focal clonic seizures include:

 

  1. Unifocal or multifocal: The seizure may involve muscle groups on one side of the body (unifocal) or multiple regions (multifocal).
  2. Synchronous or asynchronous: The movements can occur either in a coordinated manner (synchronously) or in an uncoordinated manner (asynchronously) across different muscle groups.
  3. Resistant to restraint: The movements are involuntary and cannot be suppressed by restraining the affected limb or body part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal tonic seizure: In contrast to focal clonic seizures, focal tonic seizures involve sustained posturing of a single limb, asymmetrical trunk posturing, or sustained ocular deviation. These postures are not influenced by external stimulation or restraint.

 

Option C. Spasms: Neonatal spasms are characterized by sudden, generalized jerks that last approximately 1-2 seconds. These spasms often occur in clusters and can be classified as flexor, extensor, or a combination of both. Unlike clonic seizures, spasms are not triggered or suppressed by stimulation or restraint.

 

Option D. Subtle seizure: Subtle seizures in neonates may present with less noticeable symptoms such as eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing movements, or abnormal extremity motions (e.g., rowing, swimming, cycling). Other signs may include changes in heart rate, episodes of hypertension, or apnea. These seizures are more common in premature infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal clonic seizures in neonates involve repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups that are resistant to restraint and can be unifocal or multifocal.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose


During neonatal resuscitation, suctioning is performed to clear the airway of the newborn to ensure effective breathing. The correct order for suctioning is mouth first, followed by the nose. This order is crucial because suctioning the nose first could cause the newborn to gasp and potentially aspirate any fluids or secretions present in the mouth.

 

Technical Details:

 

  • The suction catheter typically used is 12 or 14 French, and the suction pressure is maintained between 80-100 mmHg.
  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

In the given clinical scenario, the boy exhibits typical signs and symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). HSP is a type of small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by the presence of a purpuric rash, as well as arthritis and abdominal pain. Additionally, approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal complications that can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

In patients with HSP, the onset of nephritis typically follows the development of the rash. The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis is believed to be associated with the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

 

  • Here are some common types of vasculitis that can affect children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE typically presents with a butterfly malar rash over the face, especially involving the nasolabial folds. It also includes systemic symptoms like fever, joint pain, and renal involvement, but the presentation and rash pattern differ from HSP.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP presents with petechiae all over the body due to thrombocytopenia, and the patient typically has a low platelet count. Peripheral smear usually shows an increase in megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis that presents with fever, abdominal pain, skin changes like livedo reticularis, muscle and joint pain, and neuropathy. It does not typically present with the purpuric rash and renal involvement seen in HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

questions.text: Fluid of choice for a child in shock with severe acute malnutrition is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ringer lactate + 5% dextrose


In the management of a child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) who is in shock, it is crucial to select the appropriate intravenous (IV) fluid to correct fluid and electrolyte imbalances while also addressing the metabolic needs of the child. The fluid of choice in this scenario is Ringer lactate + 5% dextrose. This combination provides essential electrolytes and glucose, which is critical for children with SAM who are at high risk of hypoglycemia.

 

  • IV Fluids used in SAM with shock:
    • Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose
    • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose
    • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose

 

These fluids help manage both dehydration and electrolyte imbalances while also supplying glucose to prevent or treat hypoglycemia, which is common in children with SAM. The dextrose component is particularly important because children with SAM have depleted glycogen stores and are prone to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: This fluid is not recommend in children.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is another commonly used IV fluid but lacks both dextrose and potassium. It is not the fluid of choice in children with SAM and shock due to its lack of essential glucose and electrolytes needed for these patients.

 

Option D. Ringer lactate: Ringer lactate alone, without dextrose, is not sufficient for managing children with SAM in shock due to the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:


In children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) who are in shock, the fluid of choice is Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose to manage dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and prevent hypoglycemia.

choices.text: Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli

questions.text: Where is the most common site for a venous ulcer to develop? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli 

 

Explanation:

 

Venous ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle. The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf below the malleoli. This is the region where many of the Cockett perforators join the posterior tibial vein to the posterior arch vein (superficial vein). The chronic venous hypertension in this area leads to tissue damage and eventually ulceration when exposed to high venous and capillary pressures chronically.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli: While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers.
  • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli: Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon.
  • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh: Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Venous ulcers most commonly occur on the medial aspect of the ankle below the malleoli (gaiter area) due to the presence of perforating veins and high venous pressure in this region, especially in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella


Rubella, also known as German measles, has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission compared to the other infections listed. While rubella can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, and can lead to significant complications such as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), the overall risk of transmission at the time of birth is lower than for the other infections listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother has an active infection at the time of delivery. Neonatal herpes can result in severe outcomes, including encephalitis and disseminated disease.

 

Perinatal transmission: 25-60% with active genital lesions

Highest risk with primary maternal infection at delivery

Can cause severe neonatal herpes (encephalitis, disseminated disease)

Cesarean section recommended if active lesions

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is the most common congenital infection and has a significant risk of perinatal transmission. 

Perinatal transmission: 30-40% through breast milk, cervical secretions

Can occur through birth canal or postpartum

Usually asymptomatic in term infants

More severe in preterm infants
 

It can lead to a range of outcomes from asymptomatic infection to severe neurological impairment.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother is HBeAg positive. Without appropriate prophylaxis, many infants born to HBV-positive mothers will become chronically infected.

 

Perinatal transmission: 70-90% if mother is HBeAg positive

20-30% if HBeAg negative

Occurs during delivery through blood/body fluids

Without prophylaxis, leads to chronic infection in 90% of infected infants
 

Educational Objective:
 

Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the dermatological condition shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

The dermatological condition shown in the image is characterized by a photosensitive rash. This type of rash typically occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck, and hands. The condition depicted is pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin). Pellagra is associated with the "4 Ds": diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death. The dermatitis in pellagra is often photosensitive, meaning it worsens with exposure to sunlight, which explains the rash seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency in Vitamin A leads to conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia (dry eyes), not photosensitive rashes.

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine) causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not the skin.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C results in scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, and joint pain, but not typically photosensitive rashes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with a photosensitive rash among other symptoms like diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

 

The most frequent enzyme deficiency leading to Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which typically manifests as female pseudohermaphroditism. Female pseudohermaphroditism refers to the presentation of a genotypically normal female (46, XX) who has external genitalia that resembles those of a male. The female is virilized, which means there is a masculinization of the body, and this virilization is usually evident at birth in females and within the first 2 to 3 years of life in males.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male pseudohermaphroditism: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17a-hydroxylase deficiency due to incomplete virilization.

 

Option C. True hermaphroditism: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

 

Option D. 46 XY intersex: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 33-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, 17-Hydroxylase/17,20-Lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, typically presents as female pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by virilized genitalia in genotypic females (46, XX) at birth.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is presenting with short stature, the height of the child to parent’s height and the chronological age of the child corresponds to bone age, what is the likely condition the child is associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial short stature


The clinical scenario described here suggests familial short stature. In cases of familial short stature, the child's height is shorter than average but consistent with the heights of the parents. The key finding is that the bone age corresponds to the chronological age, which means that the child's growth is progressing at a normal rate for their bone maturity.

 

  • Bone age = Chronological age: This is typically seen in familial short stature, where the child's growth is consistent with their genetic potential. There are no delays in bone development, and the child will likely continue to grow at a rate proportional to their bone age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constitutional delay: In constitutional delay, the bone age is usually less than the chronological age, indicating delayed growth. Children with this condition often experience a late growth spurt and may eventually reach a normal adult height.

 

Option C. GH deficiency: Growth hormone (GH) deficiency is associated with short stature, but in these cases, the bone age is typically less than the chronological age, and growth is significantly impaired due to insufficient GH.

 

Option D. Normal: A normal child would have a height and bone age consistent with their chronological age and would not present with short stature relative to their parents' heights.

 

Educational Objective:


In familial short stature, the bone age corresponds to the chronological age, and the child's short stature is consistent with their genetic potential.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

 

When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects. This milestone typically occurs around 5.5 to 6 months of age. At this stage, the child is beginning to understand the differences between objects, which is why they are capable of transferring an object between hands. This action demonstrates the child's growing cognitive ability to recognize and compare different objects, an important part of early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual motor coordination: Visual motor coordination refers to the ability to use the eyes and hands together to perform tasks, such as reaching for and grasping objects. While this is important for transferring objects, the key developmental significance of transferring an object from one hand to another lies in the child's ability to compare objects.

 

Option C. Ability to handle small objects: The ability to handle small objects, such as developing a pincer grasp, occurs later, typically around 8 to 9 months of age. This milestone involves more fine motor control and precision, which is different from the broader action of transferring objects between hands.

 

Option D. Voluntary release: Voluntary release refers to the ability to let go of an object intentionally, which is generally seen after the palmar grasp reflex disappears around 4 to 6 months. However, the act of transferring an object from one hand to another is more about the child’s ability to compare objects rather than just releasing them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.

 

Developmental Milestones in 1st Yr of Life
